p: To construct the inter-organ metabolic cycles, we not only used the data from the two trans-omic subnetworks ( Figures 6A and 6B) but also added data regarding the expression of genes encoding relevant transporters and DRTFs that regulate those genes from our transcriptomic analyses. We also used the proteomic data to identify relevant transporters in liver and skeletal muscle. For the glucose-alanine cycle, we added the Asct1 and Asct2 encoding amino acid transporters to both skeletal muscle and liver ( Figure 6C) ( Freidman et al., 2020; Kandasamy et al., 2018). Although both genes were increased in expression in both organs, the DRTFs responsible for their regulation differed and neither of those transporters were detected in our proteomic data. For the glucose-lactate cycle, we added the monocarboxylate transporter Slc16a1, a major transporter of lactate ( Figure 6C) ( Halestrap, 2013). Slc16a1 was a DEP that increased in liver but was unchanged in skeletal muscle.
